description: Borrowed from Late Latin ithyphallicus, from Ancient Greek ἰθυφαλλικός (ithuphallikós), from ῑ̓θῠ́φαλλος (īthúphallos, “phallus carried in festivals of Bacchus; ode sung in honour of the phallus; dance accompanying such an ode; dancer performing such a dance”) + -ῐκός (-ikós, suffix forming adjectives meaning ‘of or pertaining to’). ῑ̓θῠ́φαλλος is derived from ἰθῠ́ς (ithús) (variant of εὐθῠ́ς (euthús, “straight”)) + φαλλός (phallós, “penis; image of a penis, phallus”). The English word can be analysed as ithyphallus +‎ -ic.
As regards the noun, compare Latin ithyphallicum (“poem with the same metre as the hymns to Priapus”).

adjectives.description: ithyphallic (comparative more ithyphallic, superlative most ithyphallic)

definitionGroups.group: (historical, Ancient Rome) Of or pertaining to the erect phallus that was carried in bacchic processions.

entries.meaning: (specifically) Of a poem or song: having the metre of an ode sung in honour of the bacchic phallus.
Of or pertaining to an upward pointing, erect penis; (specifically) of an artistic depiction of a deity or other figure: possessing an erect penis.
(poetry) Pertaining to a metrical combination of two trochees followed by one spondee.
A poem or song in an ithyphallic metre.
A lascivious or obscene poem or song.
